title: Before 1 January 2018, will Transport for London (TfL) issue a license for Uber?
preds: Uber lawsuit is likely. Taxi union interests too strong.
uber  will  just  payy  of the  london   cabbies.
No rumours or news suggesting decision imminent and only 2 days left so go for 0.
Too much tension between the black cabs over Uber
No. The taxi companies will win
London's taxi lobby has been strong enough to keep them out so far.
Depends on terms uber is willing to accept
Uber is very unlikely to receive licensing by the New Year.

“Transport Tycoon Deluxe” (video game) not “TRON”  ... because the ECJ declares, the company would fall under the jurisdiction and regulation of “transportation,” not IT.  http://www.france24.com/en/20171220-business-eu-european-court-justice-ecj-rules-uber-transport-company-europe-regulated
After today's EU ruling, I think the odds are very low that this will occur before the end of the year.

The Uber news keeps getting worse; its now claimed that British woman in Lebanon was raped and killer by an Uber driver who had a criminal record. The truth may be different, but the perception is that Uber does not vet its drivers properly, which does not help it in obtaining operating permits.
Recent news from the Waymo Case does not make Uber sound very much like a "fit and proper" company (which is the test it faces)
Appeal will not be heard until April next year
Dec 11 meeting of Transportation Board: Uber did not get license back. Court dates next year. http://www.businessinsider.sg/uber-heads-to-court-in-fight-for-london-survival/
I am adjusting to 0% (entirely unlikely) since the latest hack incident; it would be equivalent to endorsing irresponsible behaviour, so it will not happen.

The lack of the license is not really impacting Uber ops...they are "deemed" to have a license until their appeal against TfL is decided. No one would be in a tearing hurry to issue it as it's not impacting people.

The Mayor says it might take years to get license back but Uber still encouraged to build electric car charging stations and soon all new taxis need to be 0 emissions. The meeting Dec 11. https://www.theguardian.com/business-to-business/2017/nov/28/green-cabs-london-ready-electric-taxis

London has so many security challenges right now with the crowded shopping season coming up. It's just installed German style vehicle barriers. Letting the license slide would be a way for the mayor's office to reassure the public it's doing something about safety.
There are other competitors moving into Uber space in London so there will be less pressure from Londoners for a renewal of the license on Dec 12.
The cabbies have a strong lobby. It would be the nationalist thing to do in the Brexit era. The license was already turned down once.

Probably not as Uber's issues in the UK are far from over as the company is appealing a decision involving the status of drivers (whether they are employees or not). Despite the fact that the UK is a strong market for Uber, if the appeal fails, it would mean that Uber's current model would not be legal in the UK and as such, the market may not be as attractive for the company and therefore, is less likely to continue fighting issues regarding its London license.
Uber needed to make big changes based on the initital decision, with the fresh scandal (relating to data security) it's unlikely anything will be settled in the next month.
Significant changes required based on initial ruling; unlikely to be resolved by Jan 1

I'm revising my answer. Estimates originally were that the process would "likely" take several months up to a year. Considering that there were only three months to go in the year then, my starting base rate on that point would bias against a license prior to year end.  On the one hand, the TfL has cited several serious concerns. On the other hand, the concerns all appear targeted at very specific company behaviors. I believe that each is fully redressable under new company leadership. However, it remains rather remote that the TfL will resolve the issue in December regardless of the institution of new policies or mea culpas in the press. There is little urgency to resolving the issue now when the could showboat their commitment to constituents and political resolve. All the while, there's no change to business while the appeals process is ongoing.

Lowering. Hearing Dec 11 is just to set-up Court dates on their Appeal. U ER just appointed new people to head-up their UK and London operation. They can continue to operate while on Appeal. Bad press over hiding Hacking in US might also slow down the negotiations. I do not see that happening before Jan 1. The Mayor also says process might take years.

The support of Greg Hands and drivers is overwhelmed by intervening revelations of more problematic behavior at the company. And some of the ongoing troubles (hiding a security breach) are exactly the types of behavior cited by TfL.

The data breach cover up will not help matters with regulators.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-cyberattack/uber-breach-cover-up-trigger-government-probes-around-the-globe-idUSKBN1DM2F9

See headline--"Regulators to press Uber after it admits covering up data breach" "“Deliberately concealing breaches from regulators and citizens could attract higher fines for companies,” James Dipple-Johnstone, deputy commissioner of the UK Information Commissioner’s Office, said in a statement. Current British law carries a maximum penalty of 500,000 pounds ($662,000) for failing to notify users and regulators when data breaches occur." This does not bode well. But reasons still remain to give Uber a license--40,000 drivers in London and tens of thousands served.  Plus this from the Mayer--
"Uber’s change of tone bodes well for the future of the ride-hailing app in London, the city’s mayor has said.  Sadiq Khan said the apology from Uber’s chief executive and the different tone struck was an important factor as the company attempts to keep its foothold in the UK capital." Also, consider this article (which is glowing) about Uber in London--https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/27/how-uber-conquered-london It might be harder to shut Uber down than we are thinking.
Limited time before year end for any ruling

Several other recent Uber issues such as being fined in Colorado for using unqualified drivers, and paying off hackers, will not help Uber convince TfL that Uber are suitable to have a license.  http://www.newsweek.com/uber-fined-hiring-drivers-criminal-records-718095
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-cyberattack/uber-paid-hackers-to-cover-up-massive-data-breach-idUSKBN1DL2UQ

Uber's push towards driverless cars will likely further alienate it from a struggling UK government that's looking for public sympathy. Additionally, there is not a lot of pressure from the public about Uber's suspension.
Not enough time is available before January 2018 for Uber and TfL to reach an agreement.
Labour will try to stymie any advances which could be seen to impinge on workers' ( e.g. Cabbies) rights.

Increasingly unlikely as the choice for the litigation route on the matter reflects the mayor's position on equitable trade and a vote of support for the government - given its current Brexit challenges. Delaying further will allow more time for desirable frameworks to be set to support competition in the transport space.
Interesting to see more 0% and a lot less of those 10-30% forecasts

The majority of Londoners approved Khan's ruling to pull the Uber License, and that is important as Khan continues to show his strength against the struggling Teresa May. I think Khan will go very slowly before allowing Uber to get a license as he continues to leverage his new power and show solidarity with Labour. The wrinkle here is whether the Dec. 11th ruling can immediately re-instate the license without input from Khan, and I can't find the answer to that question.
Lowering. Dec 11th Licensing Board meeting will be key. This: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-britain/ubers-london-license-appeal-could-take-years-mayor-khan-idUSKBN1DG1G8
After @dsarin found an article that contradicts my thought that the mayor could override the tfl.  With a statement that it could be a number of years.
Perhaps they should change their name to Unter.  Seems more modest....
Khan has recently said the process may take years

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-britain/ubers-london-license-appeal-could-take-years-mayor-khan-idUSKBN1DG1G8
Not a bright sign for Uber, I think.

Sadiq Khan said the appeal process against a decision by Transport for London (TfL) to strip the taxi app of its operating licence could "go on for a number of years".
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-42012719
Hearing most likely starts in mid-December and may be a lengthy process.

This is quite the reversal: https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/sadiq-khan-hints-that-uber-will-get-new-london-licence-z6xb8r99z The question has never really been about if Uber gets its license restored, but rather "when."  The odds are clearly higher now, but there are really only two ways that they can get their license restored.  1)  Satisfying Demands:  As a reminder, the failings listed by the TFL were pretty serious.  How long will it take for Uber to satisfy all of the demands from the TFL and how long will it take the TFL to validate that it has met those demands (List of offenses below).  I don't think that this is plausible by year end. 2) Mayor Says Give it to Them:  The reality is that Uber is allowed to operate anyhow, why not avoid legal expenses and the like and just offer Uber the license.  Given the recent commentary from the mayor (who has ultimate authority over the TFL), I see this as a probable event.  Since #1 is not plausible in the timeline, this is the only real alternative and the odds of it have increased substantially.  The question is, can the TFL actually do this when it has demands already on the table?   Putting these together ups the odds from 0 to something a little shy of 50/50. ----------- Offenses -------------
These include: Its approach to reporting serious criminal offences.
Its approach to how medical certificates are obtained.
Its approach to how Enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) checks are obtained.
Its approach to explaining the use of Greyball in London - software that could be used to block regulatory bodies from gaining full access to the app and prevent officials from undertaking regulatory or law enforcement duties.

Raising. The mayor hinted today they might get license back and praised the contrition and compromise Uber is willing to make with the regulators. Allot of money behind Uber so would not surprise if they are back. Time frame for decision makers needs more research.
Uber's appeal of the recent decision will not be decided until long after Jan. 2018.
The first hearing is on December 11.

Based on the latest blow, it seems unlikely.
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/10/business/uk-uber-london.html
It would be difficult for the government to overcome opposition during the next few months. Only variable is the people’s political will could make it a hot issue to quickly resolve.
The time frame is too short for this to be resolved in Uber's favor, even if it were to happen eventually.

Uber lost appeal to court on how to treat its drivers. Complicates any other appeals process. Company again appealed action and I don’t think shows a change in there business strategy which will win over TfL.

Announcing that it will appeal against the court case (see @dsarin comment below) that it just lost - that found Uber was wrong in claiming it drivers were contractors and that they are in fact employees - does not make it sound like Uber has changed it way of operating. It seems it still believes that the law is for other people. If Uber was really "determined to put things right" it could start by complying with the law and then argue for a change or change its terms of employment to fit the laws. It may sound radical but its what most of us do.
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/13/uber-appeal-london-licence-tfl
While I think TfL will eventually issue a licence one uber has accepted some of its demands I don't think it will happen by 1st Jan

Uber loses court appeal against drivers' rights
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-41940018
Knowledge of London government leads me to believe they won't act anywhere near this quickly, since the appeal process will in any case last far longer than until 1/1/2018
Even with a new CEO, the corporate culture appears to be one that supports deceptive practices to target the competition.  That usually doesn't fly too well outside the US.

Uber are allowed to continue operating while their appeal is under way. This significantly reduces TFL's leverage, meaning that Uber is unlikely to accede to all of their demands, and will probably play hardball with the negotiations, as seems to be their typical business strategy. I think this makes it less likely that either side gives much ground before we get further into the legal process. The initial hearing is Dec 11 but this is literally just a short session to set the dates in 2018 for the substantive hearings. So I don't see TFL relenting before next year, since I don't see Uber capitulating to all their demands by then.
Uber's had too much controversy, they'll be trading favors for a big win.
Following and thanks @Tetbury @dsarin @Raisinville @acohen @Censusguyz @Poli_Sci_Guy for offering your reasons.
The driver who attacked in NYC was recently a driver for Uber and Lyft.

I'm revising down because of the following four factors that Uber must do to get licensed: Its approach to reporting serious criminal offences.
Its approach to how medical certificates are obtained.
Its approach to how Enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) checks are obtained.
Its approach to explaining the use of Greyball in London - software that could be used to block regulatory bodies from gaining full access to the app and prevent officials from undertaking regulatory or law enforcement duties. Checking thru Uber's twitter feeds and company announcements and seeing nothing addressing these four issues.  CEO has't said anything publicly either. Greyball is a big deal and not just in London so the fact that I can't find a public statement on it is revealing.  Maybe they're working on it.
http://content.tfl.gov.uk/taxi-and-private-hire-action-plan-2016.pdf Gedogen  (Dutch) Illegal but not illegal. allowed begrudgingly as a form of regulation.

Ultimately, my prior is that TfL will issue a license due to its impact on the vast network of drivers. However the appeal process can take 1 - 2 years while Uber is allowed to operate. This means there is no urgency for both TfL and Uber to close the case.
Very unlikely to resolve court case by 1 Jan, which ever side looses the first hearing (scheduled for 11 Dec) will almost certainly appeal.

No basis in stats in this answer. May be a hearing on 11 December, but rides are still being hailed and there doesn't appear to be a financial incentive driving the firm to resolve the case anytime soon (rather the incentive appears to be to stretch out the UK legal system appeals process).
While Uber has certainly had beyond its fair share of negativity and deficiencies, with new executive leadership and heavy lobbying, there's a tiny chance it could happen in the UK.

Very short timeframe.
First hearing is not until 12/11/17.
Process may take several months according to the article from The Independent.
When an Uber driver commits a mass-casualty truck rampage in New York City, London will surely notice.
No way, nor should London do so. Uber is grubby.
Based upon Uber’s intransigence in other markets and conservative tilt on local leadership doubt an resolution of the issues.
Very little time for a government agency to act during the holiday season, especially on a controversial issue.
The fact is, Uber can continue to operate during the appeals process.  As such the TFL will be in no hurry to resolve the issues.
There are reports of drivers sexually assaulting passengers. Allot of bad press. Would have to be able to show a much better vetting process. Not happening soon.
Following @dsarin for two reasons: he lives in the London area and he is one of the best Gjopen forecasters.
Uber,popular with Lindon public, will make amends
Establishing baseline forecast, will update based on further information and analysis.

I considered, tested, and scored four main hypotheses (with sub-hypotheses) and found them all to be supported. The hypotheses are below: - If Sadiq Khan wants to run for re-election, then there is a higher chance that Uber will be re-licensed in London by January 1st, 2018.
- If London has faced consistent congestion in the TFL in 2017, then there is a higher chance that Uber will be re-licensed in London by January 1st, 2018.
- If London’s population is increasing, then there is a higher chance that Uber will be re-licensed in London by January 1st, 2018.
- If Uber agrees to take measures to increase corporate responsibility, then there is a higher chance that Uber will be re-licensed in London by January 1st, 2018. I gave them all a score of 0.7 and thus I ended up with an average of them having 70%.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Little probability since there has not been any new announcements regarding driver compensation and enhanced passenger safety which would convince the authorities to change their current opinion.
The London transportation group has stated their objections and with pressure from the taxi drivers, there doesn’t appear to be any room for movement on the transport director’s part.

Basing my decision mostly on time and complexity of the issue. Seems like a long hard debate with strong institutions involved to be accomplished in just 2 months.....
As many have already stated, the appeal to the court will take place until December.
The only way, mentioned by others before as well, is to negotiate outside the court...if Uberwould hope for successful negotiations they might need to concede on salary, insurance, etc. losing perhaps all the competitive advantage over the official taxis.
Growing scandal about Uber, strength of tradition and union of taxis drivers.

First forecast 
Most appeals take time crowd right on target

Clearly unlikely to be a resolution via the courts before 1st January, but I think it's in both sides' interests to settle out of court.  No hurry for Uber if they can keep operating during the appeals process, but actually the sooner they have a proper licence the better for them. Note this comment:
"Uber will be able to continue operating pending an appeals process that could last a year, but the mayor indicated he would prefer a solution outside the courts."
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/05/ubers-change-of-tone-future-london-mayor-sadiq-khan-apology-licence-tfl Also note new personnel at the top of Uber and their efforts to court TfL over the last month.

Court Case on Dec 11,
"The appeal, which falls on the final day permitted by Transport for London's complex procedures, was filed in Westminster Magistrates' Court in central London and is expected to be heard on December 11, according to media reports, although the ultimate fate of Uber's operating license in the British capital may not be known for several months. "

The appeal will be heard on 11 December (https://www.thestreet.com/story/14341843/1/uber-files-appeal-with-london-transport-officials-over-licence-decision.html).  I think the outside view is about whether or not ride hailing companies can compete politically with taxi companies.  Will the interests of a public interested in cheap and convenient be enough to overcome the business interests of a niche group of companies?  And who will be able to organize better? Right now I think the tech companies will win but not without some kind of concessions.
There's some chance TfL will want to settle without a legal battle, but the timeframe for everything is drawn out and a resolution in Uber's favour by 1 Jan 2018 is very unlikely.

Appeals process will allow Uber to continue operations for an estimated 1 year timeframe.
First hearing on the appeal is Dec. 11th.  The appeals process obviously provides time for Uber to address issues while continuing to operate in London.
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/13/uber-appeal-london-licence-tfl Before a licence is issued Uber must, at a minimum, address medical and background checks for drivers, develop criminal offense reporting systems, resolve issues with its Greyball software, that blocks regulators visibility to Uber's driver app. Uber about to hire a new head for the UK unit
http://news.sky.com/story/uber-lines-up-banker-to-chair-uk-unit-amid-london-ban-appeal-11099160 Uber now faces similar issues in Brazil:
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-24/after-london-ban-uber-s-latest-regulatory-nightmare-is-brazil
There is a chance, but a remote one if the Court of Justice gives aruling in favour of UBER. Right now it seems UBER will not get the permit.

As others have mentioned, appeal process expected to take months, first hearing isn't til Dec 11th, and running in bureaucratic treacle during the holiday period. Also, TfL won't be rushing since Uber's alleged problems are related to preventing regulatory oversight.
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/13/uber-appeals-london-ban.html
The issues which led to the suspension are likely to be worked out and some form of Uber will emerge from the on going talks.

This seems very unlikely in the short time frame. Uber's appeal is expected to take months to get through (see article). https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/12/no-quick-win-for-uber-in-london-over-license-loss/
Uber has appealed, but "The first hearing on the issue is expected on December 11" so the chances of this being resolved and a license issued by January 1 are slim to none.
The appeal process for a license take months and there are only two months remaining this year with the last month filled with holidays and festivities

London is citing concerns regarding the use of Uber and avoiding police, this alongside the other complicated red tape required is going to extend the process of the appeal. Additionally, Jo Bertram, the person in charge of Uber UK has decided to leave. Meaning things are going to be slow moving with a new leader.
A lot of taxi drivers take a lot of substantial training to earn their classic jobs... that is a strong union of dissent.
Nah, let 'em sweat.  Also, there is likely some process that has to be gone through to restore a licence.  I don't know what the process is, but I'll bet it's lengthy and as painful as possible.
